fields.label_text:
One of a pair of curtains, tapestry-woven wool in 2/2 twill.
Made in the early 1870s in Yedz, in central Iran - a town usually noted for silk weaving although woollen shawl-like fabrics were also produced there.
Purchased from Murdoch Smith for £4 each.
In Europe tapestry-weaving is usually associated with large-scale wall hangings, such as the Devonshire Hunting Tapestries displayed in the next gallery.  The weft is composed of threads of different colours which do not pass across the width of the fabric, from selvedge to selvedge, but are carried backwards and forwards in small areas where they are required for the design.  Traditional tapestry uses a plain weave structure which tends to produce a fairly thick and stiff hanging.  In contrast, Iranian weavers copied the Kashmir shawl technique of using a twill weave which produces a softer fabric, more easy to fold and drape.
The weaver worked from a detailed written list giving the sequence in which the coloured wefts were to be used; the fabric was woven from the back.

fields.descriptive_line:
Middle East, Textile. Pair of textile panels, tapestry-woven wool with embroidered design of central cypress tree on red ground, Yazd, Iran, 1850-1870
[Textile Panel] Middle East, Textile. Textile panel, one of a pair, tapestry-woven wool with embroidered design of central cypress tree on red ground, Yazd, Iran, 1850-1870
[Textile Panel] Middle East, Textile. Textile panel, one of a pair, tapestry-woven wool with embroidered design of central cypress tree on red ground, Yazd, Iran, 1850-1870

fields.name: The Shah and the Engineer: Persian textiles of the 1870s

fields.physical_description:
[Textile Panel] Tapestry woven and brocaded wool, twill binding and embroidered detail.
The central panel has a red ground with a light blue niche which has a black jagged outline and a series of red, white and blue rosettes, small yellow cypress trees and isolated stylised leaves in green outlined in yellow.  All rather stylised and  isolated. The red ground is dominated by a cypress tree outlined with yellow and white banding and with 4-petalled rosettes in red and purple.  The centre of the tree is light blue with symmetrically placed motifs similar to those in the spandrels.  The tree emerges from a cauldron-like container echoing the spandrel's colours and motifs and supported by a light blue palmette like motif with an irregular central yellow lozenge and rosettes.
Half way up the tree, to either side, is a stylised candle-stick like motif and a peacock, both with a blue ground and decorated with small motifs.  At the apex to the arch is a pair of large green parakeets; their heads and neck are outlined with two lines of couched metal thread.
The rest of the field is covered with small composite motifs in offset rows: alternately a flowering plant in blue, red and purple or something reminiscent of a double-headed eagle in green, red and blue.
There are multiple borders around all four sides.  The  three widest are, from the central panel outwards:
[1] green ground with a line of small cypress trees edged in white with yellow infill flanked by a line of red rosettes and leaves.
[2] red ground with a simplified version of the flower and vase from the central panel with white or blue flower heads.
[3] dark blue ground with a red bifurcated Y-shaped motif outlined in white and blue with a diagonal boteh either side and a floral stem at the base.
This is a loom length and has about 7 shoots of white weft across both the upper and lower ends.
Warp: white, red, dark blue, yellow and green wool
Weft: white, dark red, red, pink, green, dark blue, light blue and yellow wool; all S-twist
Metal thread: silver strip wound around  cream silk.
The tension is uneven with the central panel looser than the borders.

All rather stylised and  isolated. The red ground is dominated by a cypress tree outlined with yellow and white banding and with 4-petalled rosettes in red and purple.  The centre of the tree is light blue with symmetrically placed motifs similar to those in the spandrels.  The tree emerges from a cauldron-like container echoing the spandrel's colours and motifs and supported by a light blue palmette like motif with an irregular central yellow lozenge and rosettes.
Half way up the tree, to either side, is a stylised candle-stick like motif and a peacock, both with a blue ground and decorated with small motifs.  At the apex to the arch is a pair of large green parakeets; their heads and neck are outlined with two lines of couched metal thread.
The rest of the field is covered with small composite motifs in offset rows: alternately a flowering plant in blue, red and purple or something reminiscent of a double-headed eagle in green, red and blue.
There are multiple borders around all four sides.  The  three widest are, from the central panel outwards:
[1] green ground with a line of small cypress trees edged in white with yellow infill flanked by a line of red rosettes and leaves.
[2] red ground with a simplified version of the flower and vase from the central panel with white or blue flower heads.
[3] dark blue ground with a red bifurcated Y-shaped motif outlined in white and blue with a diagonal boteh either side and a floral stem at the base.
This is a loom length and has about 7 shoots of white weft across both the upper and lower ends.
Warp: white, red, dark blue, yellow and green wool

Metal thread: silver strip wound around  cream silk.

fields.label:
One of a pair of curtains, tapestry-woven wool in 2/2 twill.
Made in the early 1870s in Yedz, in central Iran - a town usually noted for silk weaving although woollen shawl-like fabrics were also produced there.
Purchased from Murdoch Smith for £4 each.

Traditional tapestry uses a plain weave structure which tends to produce a fairly thick and stiff hanging. The weaver worked from a detailed written list giving the sequence in which the coloured wefts were to be used; the fabric was woven from the back. [1992]
fields.exhibition_history: The Shah and the Engineer: Persian textiles of the 1870s (Victoria and Albert Museum 01/05/2002-30/11/2003)
fields.bibliography: Illustrated in 'Iranian Textiles' by Jennifer Wearden and Patricia L Baker, V&A Publishing 2010 fig. 34 page 50.
fields.history_note:
This was purchased in Iran by Robert Murdoch Smith on behalf of the Museum, as part of a batch of fifteen objects. Murdoch Smith wrote: "I have purchased [these] objects which I think would be very suitable for the Museum. I will retain them at your disposal should you decide on acquiring them, and if not, I do not object to keeping them myself."

In inventory described as 'curtains' from Yazd. From Murdoch Smith £8 for 1061 and 1061A
